The character oi the substantive law ih the period intervening be· tween the final constitution oi the state and the fall oi the Republic is a subject important because it involves a discussion oi the origin and nature ol the praetor's indirect power oi legislation, and oi the hindred distinction between ius civile and ius gentium. Ius civile is one ol the two conhasted terme in two celebrated oppositione of Roman law, between which there isan intimate relation. It is op· posed, firstly, to ius gentium or naturale in general, and in this con· nection it is said (Dig. 41.1. r. pr.) to be ‘ius proprium civitatis nostrae ;' so too private law is described (Inst. i. 1. 4) as tripertitum, ‘collectum est enim ex naturalibus praeceptis, aut gentium, aut civilibus! Secondly, it is opposed to the praetorian law which was based on and drawn from the ius gentium: ‘ius civile est, quod ex legibus, plebiscitis, senatus consultis, decretis Principum, auctoritate prudentium venit: ius praetorium estquod Praetores introduxerunt adiuvandi, vel supplendi, rel corrigendi iuris civilis gratia' (Dig. 1. 1. y)².
